Title:
Similar communities of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi among the
forest ecosystems in Japans temperate region
Keywords:
Chamaecyparis obtusa, Glomeraceae, Glomeromycotina,
MaarjAM, SSU rDNA, Temperate forest
Abstract:
We investigated arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungal
communities in Japans temperate region based on a partial small subunit
of a nuclear ribosomal RNA gene (SSU rDNA) sequences obtained from plant
roots in secondary forests and/or Chamaecyparis obtusa plantations from
eight study sites. The study sites were in a region that extends 550 km
North to South and 890 km East to West. In the secondary forests
examined, various AM plants of the families Lauraceae, Sapindaceae,
Rutaceae, Araliaceae, Rosaceae, etc. were found; the plant family
composition was determined based on the examined roots, which were
examined using chloroplast DNA trnL, and was significantly distinguished
from that of the plantations. Of the AM fungal operational taxonomic
units (OTUs), which were clustered at a 97% similarity threshold of the
partial SSU rDNA sequences, three dominant OTUs constituted 48.0% of the
total reads, and the most dominant OTU was found in all study sites
except one. Despite the investigation of various forest plants in the
region, statistical analyses of the communities of AM fungi suggest that
they were neither diversified among the study sites nor distinguished
from the forest types. These results suggest that similar AM fungal
communities are primarily constituted by some dominant AM fungi in
forest ecosystems in Japans temperate region. Furthermore, BLAST
searches against MaarjAM, a database of AM fungal sequences, suggest
that the dominant AM fungi in temperate Japanese forests are distributed
throughout forest ecosystems worldwide.
